Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Ocean Tale of Two Climates: Modern and Last Glacial Maximum
Award.AbstractNarration:
The paleoclimate record shows that the climatic changes between glacial and interglacial periods were associated with large swings in atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations. It is reasonably well established that the ocean was a major sink for the carbon lost by the atmosphere during the cold glacial spells. Furthermore observations suggest that the ocean water masses underwent major rearrangements during these periods. The chain of events by which the ocean state and circulation changed, however, is still unknown and represents a roadblock in our understanding of the great redistributions of carbon that occurred during glacial cycles. Our lack of a quantitative understanding of the changes in ocean circulation and atmospheric carbon dioxide during glacial climates represents a serious deficiency in our understanding of the climate system and shakes our confidence in projections of future climate. The goal of our project is to make progress towards a more quantitative understanding of glacial climates by combining emerging theories of the deep ocean circulation and observations. The project will also provide ideal training for a student and a postdoc.

This project attempts to draw a quantitative picture of the differences in the ocean state and circulation between the present and the Last Glacial Maximum, which is consistent both with our current theoretical understanding of the deep ocean circulation, as well as with available modern and paleo observations. To achieve this goal, the scientists will use a combination of forward and inverse modeling. The forward models will develop a mechanistic understanding of the circulation, with a focus on the changes between the present and the Last Glacial Maximum, while the inverse models will test the consistency of the emerging picture with observations. The study builds on a hypothesis that argues that the permanent (summer) sea ice extent around Antarctica exerts a strong control on the Southern Ocean buoyancy fluxes and in turn on the deep ocean circulation. This qualitative hypothesis will be developed into a quantitative "diagnostic theory" of the deep ocean circulation and carbon storage during the Last Glacial Maximum. The research has three main parts: (1) Improving the mechanistic understanding of the present-day deep ocean circulation and stratification, (2) Analyzing the impact of increased permanent sea ice extent on the deep circulation while establishing the consistency of the emerging picture with available observational data. (3) Investigating the connection between the modified ocean circulation/stratification and the changes in ocean carbon storage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to improve our understanding of changes in the deep ocean circulation between the present and the last glacial maximum (~20 thousand years ago), when the climate was much colder than today. Proxy data shows that the climatic changes between the last glacial maximum and the present interglacial period were associated with a large increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations. It is reasonably well established that the deep ocean was a major sink for the carbon lost by the atmosphere during the cold glacial spells. We also have substantial evidence for re-arrangements in the deep ocean circulation and water masses between these time periods. However, the specifics of how and why the deep ocean circulation changed, and whether the changes in the ocean circulation caused the lower atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations, remains unclear. Understanding the causes for deep ocean circulation changes and their role in modulating atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations is not only crucial to decipher the mysteries behind the prominent glacial-interglacial climate swings of the past million years, but also provides us with important insights into the workings of the climate system, which can improve our confidence in future climate predictions. 

Our results show that changes in the deep ocean circulation and stratification between the present and last glacial maximum can be explained as a direct result of global temperature change (Jansen 2017). Colder temperatures lead to enhanced sea-ice formation around Antarctica. The associated brine rejection leads to a strongly enhanced deep ocean stratification and ultimately a shoaling of the Atlantic overturning circulation, consistent with proxy data for the last glacial maximum (Jansen and Nadeau 2016, Jansen 2017, Marzocchi and Jansen 2017).

We also found that the changes in sea ice and ocean circulation expected for a colder climate, such as the LGM, can strongly affect deep ocean carbon storage and hence atmospheric CO2 concentrations. Computer simulations suggest that changes in sea ice and deep ocean circulation are likely to explain about half of the observed atmospheric CO2 drawdown between the present and the last glacial maximum. To explain the full drawdown observed in the data, additional mechanisms, such as changes in ocean biology, need to be invoked. 

Our results also resolve an apparent contradiction between data for the last glacial maximum and computer model predictions for the 21st century climate, both of which suggest a weaker and shallower Atlantic overturning circulation compared to today, despite the fact that one represents a much colder climate while the other represents a warmer climate. Using theory and computer simulations, we show that the data can be understood if we account for the fundamental difference between the response of the ocean circulation to surface temperature change on time scales of decades to centuries (relevant for 21st century climate change) versus the millennial time-scale response relevant for the glacial cycles (Jansen et al. 2018). Our results thus reconcile climate predictions with past climate data, thus strengthening our confidence in both. 

Apart from contributing to our understanding of deep ocean circulation and its role in climatic changes, the project provided training for a postdoctoral research scientist (Dr. Alice Marzocchi), who has since moved on to a permanent position as a researcher at the National Oceanographic Center in Southampton, UK.
